discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Is DAI credit or a currency?

content.content: One of the biggest split in the community those days seems to come from the fact that DAI is credit for some people while others see a currency (a system of money where there can be many monetary medium but sharing the same unit of account, DAI). If DAI is credit in the $-currency, you are a promise to get $1 and be valued $1. The least you fulfill this role, the less you have moneyness. You can enforce that by custodying higher level money, in which case you are a money certificate. Or you can use fractional-reserve banking and therefore you are a fiduciary media. There are some questions that a fiduciary media in a free banking system could work. If you are want to be a currency (i.e. depeging and being your own unit of account), then you need to be generally accepted somewhere. This means that goods and services in this somewhere (physical or the metaverse) are expressed/pegged to DAI. Then you can have second order effect as DAI would be a fiat currency. Stability (or whatever objective of the currency) would be created by dealing with the interest rates. Aren’t we (the crypto space) working toward a hard currency (BTC or ETH) with a disregard of fiat currencies? Is it something temporary until those harder currency take the lead (but too volatile for now?). Is the control of the currency by a democracy bad but control of the currency by a capitalistic system good? It also doesn’t mean that a credit form of money can’t become a currency. This is what happened to the US dollar. It was first a credit instrument pegged to gold before moving to a currency. But a key point is that this transition was done when the US Dollar was a generally recognized mean of exchange. Things where expressed in $, no longer in ounce of gold. No right or wrong answers here, just a temperature check.     DAI is credit DAI is a currency DAI is credit but should be a currency asap DAI is something else Abstain Don’t know/don’t care     0 voters

content.content: Are dollars money or is it a promissory note with the FED?

Why can’t it be both? On one hand Dai is a currency in a “local” context but certainly is a dollar credit in a more “international” context. Kind of akin to inside/outside money dichotomy depending on who’s facilitating the transaction. This seems true of traditional currency systems as well. The local market for Dai can be considered the Maker protocol or any native marketplace. Maker can pursue policies that make it more attractive on an international basis (like a tight dollar peg) while also pursuing productive domestic policies (i.e. tuning SF rates or D3M integrations). There is clearly groups within the community that care more abut some markets over others, but I don’t think they have to be mutually exclusive as your poll indicates. Happy to be educated tho.

Can’t it just be both? A currency is only a value that has a numerical link, DAI has a numerical link that gives it value, and of course it can be used for a credit unit, the issue is that if it is used more for credit units than for P2P exchanges, it does not it will have a specific functionality, the greater exposure of DAI in the population much easier than increasing capitalization

I and others probably would appreciate at least some idea of what definitions you are using. ‘credit’ implies all kinds of things. ‘currency’ another.    merriam-webster.com    Definition of CREDIT reliance on the truth or reality of something; the balance in a person's favor in an account; an amount or sum placed at a person's disposal by a bank… See the full definition         merriam-webster.com    Definition of CURRENCY circulation as a medium of exchange; general use, acceptance, or prevalence; the quality or state of being current : currentness… See the full definition      and then there is    merriam-webster.com    Definition of UNIT OF ACCOUNT a monetary unit or measure of value (as a coin) in terms of which accounts are kept and values stated… See the full definition      Abstained here because imo definitions weren’t really laid out clearly. I have long maintained that since DAI is only redeemed by borrowers for collateral (or by DAI holders during an ES for a collateral share) that DAI is only a ‘unit of collateral on account’.   That is it.   DAI isn’t a credit (because this assumes there is something the holder can exchange for at all times and this generally is only true for borrowers). Now whether DAI fulfills as a currency your point stands.     SebVentures:  If you are want to be a currency (i.e. depeging and being your own unit of account), then you need to be generally accepted somewhere. This means that goods and services in this somewhere (physical or the metaverse) are expressed/pegged to DAI.   This was something during the 2011-2014 years of Bitcoin that was watched carefully.  How many places accepted Bitcoin for ‘products’.   BTC and ETH for the most part have been rejected as a medium of exchange for products with many important vendors mostly due to price volatility causing issues with normal capital flows in the business both from revenue sides (since you had to convert crypto to taxable cash to book the tx) and in refunds.   For some time I wondered why Maker wasn’t building a DAI marketplace, but then we cycle back to the same business issues (converting DAI to local currency to book the sale(fees/overhead), and back to refund).  It wasn’t clear building a DAI marketplace really would grow DAI use nor how much this would cost.

content.content: For currency, I linked to the Wikipedia definition of a system of money.     SebVentures:  currency  (a system of money where there can be many monetary medium but sharing the same unit of account, DAI).    A more general definition is that a currency is a system of money in common use within a specific environment over time, especially for people in a nation state.[3] Under this definition, U.S. dollars (US$), euros (€), Indian rupee (₹), Japanese yen (¥), and pounds sterling (£) are examples of (government-issued) fiat currencies. Currencies may act as stores of value and be traded between nations in foreign exchange markets, which determine the relative values of the different currencies.[4] Currencies in this sense are either chosen by users or decreed by governments, and each type has limited boundaries of acceptance  For credit, I would refer to fiduciary media.  Fiduciary media consist of the proportion of perfect money substitutes which a bank issues but does not fully back by physical monetary units (i.e. gold or paper money) in their vaults. [1] Fiduciary media can exist in many forms including credit notes, checks or drafts.  I hope it clarifies.

MakerMan:  and others probably would appreciate at least some idea of what definitions you are using.   I hastily clicked Currency because that’s what I want it to be. But I agree that we need clearer definition especially as DAI would be a currency with quite different properties than most others.

DAI is debt. I’d want it to be currency and good money but it’s not that. Today DAI is USD denominated debt that is over collateralized by (mostly) volatile assets. This is primarily because DAI is minted by undergoing a CDP agreement with the smart contract, which has an interest rate and carries a risk premium. The risk premium is typically represented by how far it deviates from the peg, but this is imperfect due to the PSMs and the serious information asymmetry that exists in crypto. It’s rare that DAI is used to pay for goods and services outside Maker so we can’t consider it a currency or money. DAI is also not a commodity. Bitcoin is. Eth likely is. But it’s not produced from human/machine capital and/or scarce natural resources and isn’t produced by more than one entity. Because it doesn’t come with dividend or voting rights I would not consider DAI to be a security (doesn’t meet the Howie test). Alternatively DAI could be considered a derivative instead of a debt instrument. Whereby the value of DAI is derived from USD spot price of the underlying collateral and I’ve had this discussion with multiple regulators.

ekryski:  It’s rare that DAI is used to pay for goods and services outside Maker so we can’t consider it a currency or money.   But DAI is being used as a store of value which is one of the main properties of a currency. Agree that it needs to be more attractive to be a medium of exchange but forward-looking it seems that it will become cheaper faster and easier to do so.

I think it is very ambiguous what DAI is, but if we go to the practical, the only way to issue DAI is with debt, being for the protocol each DAI as a debt contracted for the same and that must be honoured with the same, no matter what use the other users are going to give it.

Agree its very unique but you can hold DAI without having debt pledged to the protocol (e.g. exchanging ETH for DAI). The PEG is maintained with collateral, usually debt (crypto-vaults or RWA) but mostly from the PSM.

ekryski:  Alternatively DAI could be considered a derivative instead of a debt instrument.    That would make it a S-E-C-U-R-I-T-Y… if it’s a derivative of a debt instrument. Then, in the U.S. the SEC may have regulatory jurisdiction over the issuer and the platforms that trade it. If it’s a derivative of a commodity, the CFTC may have jurisdiction. If the reference asset(s) for DAI are a blend of commodities (eth??) and securities (treasuries, other crypto assets), what does that mean? Would the characterization of DAI depend on the vault or specific collateral that minted each individual DAI? So might DAI therefore in fact have qualities of being non-fungible? Aside: Proof-of-work mining origin is really very helpful in giving a crypto asset true qualities of a commodity from a pure common sense perspective. Energy is neither created nor destroyed in the universe they say, so electricity generated and flowing through a system to produce a unique product looks a lot like catching beavers, and skinning them to produce a desirable beaver pelt that was once both a valuable scarce commodity, money and currency:   coins.nd.edu   Money Substitutes in New Netherland and Early New York From Coins of Colonial and Early America, an exhibit of over 250 items from Massachusetts silver to the provisional half disme of 1792. Features high-resolution images and detailed descriptions.       The earliest mention of the value of a beaver pelt in the New Netherland laws appears in the mid 1650’s when the West India Company tried to devalue the price of beaver. This was during the height of the beaver trade when about 80,000 pelts were being exported annually. The increased imports resulted in an oversupply of furs which led to a decrease in the value of the beaver in Amsterdam. Therefore, the West India Company was simply trying to reflect the economic situation by devaluing the beaver in New Netherland, so it would be relative to the value in Amsterdam.   This became a major problem because in New Netherland the beaver was not just a commodity. It was also a negotiable instrument like our paper currency and even more, it was the standard by which other significant money substitutes were measured. To devalue the beaver was to devalue the currency. However for the Amsterdam directors, if the beaver was not devalued, the profit margin for the West India Company stockholders would diminish and the situation would continue to deteriorate until the supply was brought in line with demand.  ACREinvest abstains. We are not saying what we think DAI is, but we love this conversation! P.S. Time to spin up some ETC vaults… IMO Merge Risks and Market Impacts - #11 by ACREinvest
